subject: Re: How to test a method that logs to a file
msgSnippet: I agree that it s about notifications not logging. Hide the logging behind a domain-focused interface. I m not sure if a listener approach is always best.
messageBody:
I agree that it's about notifications not logging. Hide the logging
behind a domain-focused interface.

I'm not sure if a listener approach is always best. Having listeners
attached may not be required for the object to function, but it's
probably required for the application to function.

So you could make an argument for injection, since it's harder to
forget to wire in a listener if you're forced to supply one in the
constructor!

By the way Steve Freeman's written a good article on the topic here:
http://www.mockobjects.com/2007/04/test-smell-logging-is-also-feature.html

David



--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Nat Pryce" <nat.pryce@...> wrote:

> Logging is usually not a dependency. It's not *required* for the
object's

is doing.
>
